sect1.title: CASE 67
sect1.para: A 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension and prediabetes presented to ophthalmology with a painful left eye and decreased visual acuity over the preceding 6 months, with right eye vision unchanged. During the initial presentation with an outside provider 6 months prior, the patient was diagnosed with varicella-zoster keratitis and treated with valacyclovir and prednisone without improvement. At present, left eye visual acuity was limited to hand motion and a cornea stromal melt was observed on a slit lamp exam.

sect1.para: The patient underwent a penetrating keratoplasty (PKP), removing the damaged cornea and transplanting with a donor cornea button. sect1.para: Upon histopathologic diagnosis of Acanthamoeba keratitis, the patient was started on polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) eye drops. Over the ensuing few months, symptoms continued despite treatment with PHMB and the addition of oral miltefosine, culminating in progressive corneal melt and need for a second PKP.

listitem.para: 7. What other severe infections are caused by free-living ameba and how are they diagnosed?

sect1.para: 1. Keratitis is an inflammation of the cornea. In infectious keratitis, there is destruction of the corneal epithelium and stroma. There are three common forms of keratitis: (i) cases associated with contact lens use; (ii) keratitis following trauma, including postsurgical infections; and (iii) viral keratitis. Bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses can all cause infectious keratitis (1), with the likelihood depending on the level of immunosuppression of the patient and the mode of exposure.

Bacterial: Staphylococcus aureus; coagulase-negative staphylococci; streptococci, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, viridans group streptococci, and beta-hemolytic streptococci; Bacillus species; Cutibacterium acnes; and Moraxella species are some of the most common bacterial species encountered. For contact lens wearers, Gram-negative bacilli found in water, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Serratia marcescens, are more likely. In postsurgical keratitis, rapidly growing mycobacteria are also causes of infectious keratitis, also linked to water exposure.

Fungal: Fungal keratitis can be separated into yeasts and molds. The most common yeasts include Candida species and Cryptococcus neoformans. Mold infections are most common following trauma and implantation of fungal spores, with Fusarium species, Aspergillus species, Paecilomyces species, and dematiaceous (melanin-producing) molds being the most commonly isolated. Prototheca, an alga, has also been associated with posttrauma keratitis.

Parasitic: For contact lens wearers, the most common predisposing activities for infectious keratitis include (i) practicing poor contact lens hygiene; (ii) replacing contact lens solutions with tap water; and (iii) wearing lenses when showering or when swimming in freshwater, swimming pools, or hot tubs. In addition to some of the waterborne bacteria, poor contact lens hygiene is associated with parasitic keratitis, namely infection with Acanthamoeba. Additionally, microsporidia, protozoan parasites related to fungi, are a post-trauma cause.

Viral:A large number of viruses have been implicated in keratitis, depending on the patient’s level of immunosuppression and mode of infection (i. e., hematogenous or direct inoculation). The most common causes include the herpesviruses, including herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), HSV-2, varicella-zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus.
2. The arrows in Fig. 67.1 are pointing to trophozoites of Acanthamoeba.

3. Acanthamoeba is a free-living ameba. Prolonged contact of Acanthamoeba with the eyes, usually through poor contact lens cleaning or swimming with contact lenses, can result in Acanthamoeba keratitis.

4. The diagnosis can be made from surgical pathology from a corneal biopsy, visualizing cysts or trophozoites in the infected tissue. For Acanthamoeba, specialized culture can be performed. Briefly, tissue is minced in Page’s ameba saline, which notably has lower concentrations of sodium chloride than physiologic or phosphate-buffered saline (2). A small amount of this homogenate is added to an agar plate growing Escherichia coli or Klebsiella aerogenes (a bacterial food source for the amebae). The inoculated agar plate is observed daily for 1 week under ×100 magnification looking for presence of amebae. These cultures are time-consuming, require specialized media that may not be readily available near the patient, require technical expertise, and carry significant risk of contamination. More recently, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for detection of Acanthamoeba has become the preferred diagnostic method (3). NAAT can be performed from a corneal biopsy, paraffin-embedded tissue, corneal scraping, corneal swab, and in some cases contact lenses or lens case. Testing is available at major reference laboratories and offers an opportunity for simplified diagnostic workup.

5. Acanthamoeba species are found throughout the world (4). They are found in water and soil, in both natural and man-made environments (e. g., heating/cooling units and household plumbing)(5). Acanthamoeba exists in the environment in both cyst and trophozoite forms. While the trophozoite is the infectious form, inoculation with cysts can also result in infection through conversion to the trophozoite form within the host. Figure 67.2 depicts the life cycle of Acanthamoeba and modes of infection.

6. Treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis is challenging, and delayed diagnosis can contribute to poor clearance of the organisms as cysts in the tissue are highly resistant to therapy and can result in relapsed disease (2, 6). First-line therapy can include a combination of PHMB and chlorhexidine. Recent evidence has shown that the addition of oral miltefosine can assist in clearance in treatment-refractory cases (7).

7. Infections with free-living amebae are relatively uncommon (5). In addition to Acanthamoeba species, Balamuthia mandrillaris and Naegleria fowleri cause human infections. Shared traits among these organisms include their global distribution, soil and water environmental habitats, and presence of both cyst and trophozoite stages in nature (Naegleria has a third flagellate stage as well).

Inoculation with Acanthamoeba and Balamuthia can occur through the upper airway or breaks in the skin. Hematogenous spread of these organisms can reach the central nervous system, resulting in a slowly progressive neurologic disease termed granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE). Clinical manifestations of these organisms, including GAE, are most common in immunocompromised individuals. Diagnostic options for GAE are similar to Acanthamoeba keratitis, including surgical pathology, culture, or NAAT from tissue. NAAT can also be performed on cerebrospinal fluid. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS), from cerebrospinal fluid and plasma, has also shown the ability to detect these free-living amebae (7, 8).

sect1.para: In contrast, infection with N. fowleri causes the rapidly progressive primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), which is nearly always fatal and has no predilection for immunocompromised individuals (9). PAM occurs when ameba-containing water contacts the nasal mucosa, usually through improper sinus irrigation or swimming in warm, stagnant, or improperly chlorinated water. Trophozoites can migrate up the olfactory nerves and into the brain. Diagnostic options for Naegleria include the previously mentioned culture, NAAT, mNGS, and histopathology. Notably, only trophozoites, no cysts, are present in tissue with Naegleria. In suspected cases of PAM, direct mounts of cerebrospinal fluid can be used to detect the motile trophozoites.

listitem.para: Infectious keratitis can be caused by a variety of bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses. The likelihood of each depends on the mode of inoculation and the immune status of the patient. Some pathogens, particularly bacteria, represent sight-threatening emergencies.
Acanthamoeba is a free-living ameba that can cause Acanthamoeba keratitis.
Risk factors for Acanthamoeba keratitis include poor contact lens hygiene.
Diagnosis of Acanthamoeba keratitis relies on histopathology, NAAT, and culture.

Treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis is complicated and can involve a combination of topical polyhexamethylene biguanide and/or chlorhexidine with surgical procedures. Relapse can occur if cyst forms remain viable after treatment.

Free-living amebae cause additional serious infections, including granulomatous amebic encephalitis (Acanthamoeba and Balamuthia) and primary amebic meningoencephalitis (Naegleria). These infections are diagnosed through histopathology, culture, NAAT, or mNGS.
